posts.raw_content:
In France, paternity tests can only be conducted through judicial proceedings, requiring a court order, and unauthorized testing is illegal, punishable by fines and imprisonment.  If you order a paternity test via the Internet or by telephone in France, not only may the shipment be confiscated by the customs but you risk a year in prison and a fine of € 15,000 (Article 226-28 of the Penal Code ). The Supreme Court, the civil matters section, has sole jurisdiction to hear actions concerning filiation.  

Courts require probable cause like infertility or absence during conception, and do not allow anyone with mere suspicions to do paternity testing. 

Refusal of the test does NOT automatically count as an admission of guilt.  "French judges can interpret this refusal as a confession or admission of paternity, allowing them to establish filiation based on other evidence presented. This legal principle stems from France's Civil Code and filiation laws, which prioritize judicial oversight to protect family stability and privacy."  So not only is not an admission of guilt by law, merely one way the judge can choose to interpret it, but the civil code pushes them to prioritize protecting family stability. This is why they're far more likely to consider it an admission of guilt when the father refuses (forcing a father to stay legally and fiscally responsible for a child which may not be theirs) but not when the mother refuses (keeping a father from finding out the truth and leaving the family).

In Germany, the law requires the consent from BOTH parents in order for testing to be allowed.  Under the Genetic Diagnostics Act, paternity tests are only allowed with the consent of the mother. Otherwise, a fine of up to 5000 euros may be imposed.

Bodily autonomy doesn't apply as paternity tests do not require the mother's DNA (even official ones ordered by court), and in both France and Germany, parents are subject to joint parental authority, meaning only one parent needs to consent for medical procedures except in cases of serious medical procedures like surgery, invasive treatments, or experimental procedures.  A DNA swab clearly does not fall under any of these.  

Similar laws exist in Israel, where private testing is banned, and courts avoid allowing testing when it is likely to reveal the child is not the father's.  

These 3 are the only nations with laws like these; Switzerland is a close fourth but is not quite as comprehensive.
posts.author: Electricutie
posts.title: Laws in France, Germany, Israel, and Switzerland exist to prevent fathers from finding out their children are not biologically theirs and to protect cheating mothers for the sake of their illegitimate children
